bug.short_desc: Migrate to the Eclipse NLS system for the Babel editor

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 86678 patch to migrate to NLS
Currently the Babel editor uses a messages bundle relying on the "normal" architecture to get Strings.
Eclipse uses an other way to handle messages, by subclassing the NLS class and declaring static Strings.
Attached is a patch that transforms the Babel editor to rely on the Eclipse NLS system. It changes the structure of the fragment a lot: the nl folder is removed, to place the French properties in the same package as the default properties.
I am an Eclipse committer over the STP project: as such I hope this contribution will not raise IP issues.

Since I want to keep the nl folder/structure for this plugin as it is also a good practice and I would like to promote this concept, I would like to close this ticket unless there is a strong case for it.
Since Eclipse is meant to support the NL directory structure at its core, maybe we could have a class like the one your are proposing support the NL structure? It would seem like a logical step forward.
In which case, I would gladly discuss re-introducing it and even maybe, have its creation automatically synched-up with the messages editor.

I don't mean to restart that debate.
However I think the best practice is: - use standard property resource bundles when the strings are loaded from the plugin's code. - use nl-drectory structure only for other files that are not properties or not loaded from the code of the plugin itself. Here is the link: http://help.eclipse.org/stable/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/product_def_nl.htm
The nl-directory structure can be used as an alternative to standard java resources but I don't think it is a best practice. They had to support something else than standard java resource bundles so they can internationalize files they would not be able to internationalize otherwise. It is not a best practice: it is because they had to add another mechanism to internationalize splash.bmp, plugin.properties and fragment.properties.
Inside the java code, the best practice is to use the NLS object. But frankly it does not matter and the final choice is up to the plugin developer.
